days.description: Welcome to web development: At the beginning there was only HTML, years later CSS appeared, and that's how the web 1.0 came to life
days.instructions: You have 30 min to explain how HTTP works sending-receiving text between servers & clients, how the browsers interpret that text as HTML, CSS or JS and then start coding. Start the postcard HTML on the screen and students should finishe it. Use float layout pursposes instead of display inline-block.
key-concepts: HTML is similar to Word: Headings, paragraphs, etc
days.teacher_instructions: You have 30 min to explain how HTTP works sending-receiving text between servers & clients, how the browsers interpret that text as HTML, CSS or JS and then start coding. Start the postcard HTML on the screen and students should finishe it. Use float layout pursposes instead of display inline-block.
days.extended_instructions:
# Day 1 - Web Development 1. Present the academy and team (3min). 2. Students present itself (5min). 3. Sign informal agreement (3min). 4. Make sure everyone is on gitpod and explain gitpod (10min). - What is a workspace. - Install the gitpod plugin. - How to run the HTML boilerplate. 5. Introduce them to BreatheCode: - How to login, see your, your todos, etc. - How to create a new project using the boilerplates. - How to deliver an assignment. 6. Master-class about The internet, HTTP, and HTML (20min). 7. Students code the postcard HTML (45min). 8. Master-class about CSS (10min). 9. Students code the postcard CSS (45min). ##### Present the academy - 6pm Small Presentation - Who we are: Each teacher presents itself. - Get everyone to introduce themselves: ``` First name and last 1. What would you like to be called? 2. What do you do now? (for work) 3. What do you plan on doing when you become a developer? ``` ##### Master Class **Client vs Server** Explain how for student to access Google, their website is hosted on another computer called a ‚ÄúServer‚Äù that they own. The student would have to communicate from their local computer (called a ‚Äúclient‚Äù), to get the website from the server so they can view and use it. **HTTP Request vs Response** The method used for this communication is called HTTP, which stands for Hyper Text Transfer Protocol. The way that you get the website is by sending a ‚ÄúRequest‚Äù to the server. This tells the server what website or resource you are looking to view/use. The server then responds with the information. The server then sends a response, which tells will confirm the receipt of the request and let your computer know that it will begin sending data. (second day content) This back and forth process will continue with more Request=>Response pairs until you have finished loading your remote resource. (in this case, Google ‚Äì second day content) **Everything is text!** With HTTP, it‚Äôs important to focus on the first ‚ÄòT‚Äô in the acronym, which stands for ‚ÄòText‚Äô. In this protocol, everything is sent back and forth as TEXT. While there are other protocols out there, for now, we want to remember that with HTTP ‚Äì Everything is TEXT. **Browser Interpretation** After your browser uses the HTTP protocol and receives the data as text, it then has the job of interpreting that text and converting it to the correct visual format. (What do you think that text is converted into? Open your cheat sheet for HTML and guess. Images, tables, videos, animations, etc) **HTML vs CSS** So that the developers that made Google (or any other website) can create the experience you know and love, they have to use certain languages. The three most commonly used ones in front end are HTML, CSS, and Javascript. HTML is like the framework for any website. It‚Äôs good to think of it as a house. If you are building a house, you need a foundation and a frame before you build walls and make everything pretty. After you use the HTML to make that framework, you can make the website pretty by using CSS. **Always Be Closing and Indentation Matters** When you start coding today, everything is going to be done in blocks of code. Each block is self contained so you always have the same flow with creating one. First you open the block, then you close the block. In 4geeks,we have a saying for this `‚ÄúALWAYS BE CLOSING‚Äù`. Let‚Äôs take a look at a typical block of HTML (setup a `` `` and `

` on the board) Notice there is a start and end to the block. These opening and closing statements are called **‚ÄúTags‚Äù**. Each statement of a code document also has it‚Äôs own indentation, so that it is more legible to any developers that review your code. This is VERY important as you always want your coding to be understandable by other people working on projects with you. Now, to get acquainted with this a bit, were going to try an exercise. > Have students open and start the postcard with HTML only, no CSS) > > Here is where they start coding the html of the postcard for 45 min, everyone should be able to finish the html before starting with the css. **CSS Selectors (basic ones)** Now that you have created your first project in HTML, you have to consider the styling that will be needed. As we discussed before, the HTML provides all of the elements on the page, but the CSS is what gives those elements size, color, position, and even transitions or animations. **Let‚Äôs talk about how CSS works.** CSS allows you to set the properties we just mentioned (like size and color) by targeting that element. The targeting occurs by using something called Selectors, which are basically the syntax that you use to define what you are targeting. ``` Some basic selectors are: ID, CLASS, and ELEMENT ``` CSS formatting is always done as follows: ```selector { property: value; }``` `ID` is something that you can set up on an HTML tag that UNIQUELY identifies that specific tag (whether it‚Äôs a Paragraph, Div, or Section) `ID` is a property of the element This is done by adding the property `id=‚Äùname‚Äù` for example: ```html

``` When you have defined it in your HTML, the targeting in your CSS would be: `#myDiv` The `#` (hash/octothorpe) tells the interpreter that you are targeting an `ID` Class is similar to ID, in that, it helps to identify the specific element but it is NOT Unique **Class is a property of the element** An element can have many classes or not Similar to ID, you would add `class=‚Äùname‚Äù`, for example: ```html
``` Element is just as it sounds. Each type of tag that you use in your HTML has an Element Selector in CSS. You don‚Äôt need a special property in your html for this as it‚Äôs a broad range selector, meaning that when used alone it will select all of that element type. An example would be div elements. To select all divs in css, you would just use the div selector: ```css div { //some css rule here } ``` In CSS, selectors can be combined to enhance the specificity of your targeting. Rule of thumb goes that the more specific CSS will take precedence.

days.description: Then, websites got popular and CSS evolved to enable amazing layouts with boxes and also a ritch set of CSS Selectors
days.instructions: Connecting CSS & HTML: Finish the postcard and start the Instagram Feed. Review all the key concepts with your students.
key-concepts: Do not use ID as CSS selectors (use specificity)
days.teacher_instructions: Connecting CSS & HTML: Finish the postcard and start the Instagram Feed. Review all the key concepts with your students.
days.extended_instructions:
# Day 2 - Web Development

Welcome everyone and ask how many got around to the reading.
Make sure everyone has access to BreatheCode platform and also to the replit exercises.
Get feedback about repl‚Äôit from those using it already.
 
Quick Recap of previous day with additional points about Request/Response. (10-15 min)
 
***Mention that when they get to the repl‚Äôit for HTML tables and CSS, they will see how some elements have properties for color and border, which is how the web was styled before CSS.***
 
## Lecture `(20min)`
 
1. Do not use ID as CSS selectors (use specificity)
  * As we discussed previously, CSS utilizes Specificity for targeting.
  * When we talked about ID and Class selectors, I mentioned that in most cases it‚Äôs better to use classes because they are reusable.
  * Try to avoid ID selectors unless you absolutely need them. It‚Äôs possible to achieve the same effect as an ID selector by using specificity.
  * If you google ‚Äúcss specificity calculator‚Äù, you can find tools that help you to calculate specificity of your selectors, but you shouldn‚Äôt need them if you understand the basic rules.
  * Review how specificity works. 
    1. Combine selectors to get more specific about which element you are styling
    2. w3schools breaks down specificity hierarchy in this order (from greatest to least specific):
      * Inline styles - An inline style is attached directly to the element to be styled.
      
        For Example: 
        ```html 
        <h1 style="color: #ffffff;">
        ```
      * IDs - An ID is a unique identifier for the page elements, such as #navbar.
      * Classes, attributes and pseudo-classes - This category includes .classes, [attributes] and pseudo-classes such as :hover, :focus etc.
      * Elements and pseudo-elements - This category includes element names and pseudo-elements, such as h1, div, :before and :after.
      * You can read more about specificity on breathco.de
2. Before & ::After Selectors
  * Help to insert content or styling before or after an element
  * This is really helpful as it allows you to do cool things like create interesting block quote effects. You can add giant quotation marks or symbols.
3. DRY Technique
  * Ask if anyone remembers what we said DRY Programming means?
  * Don‚Äôt repeat yourself
  * Everything must have a single representation, don‚Äôt repeat elements unnecessarily. (example: reusable classes instead of same property repeated over and over)
  * A good example of this would be, if I was going to apply a color blue to 5 parts of the site, I could add the ```color: blue;```
   property to every area of my CSS, or the better practice is to... 
    1. Create a class that will apply the blue color and attach it to the items that need it. 
    2. Or, Create a multi-part css statement. Multiple selectors that are comma separated to target several specific elements.
    For Example:  ```.myHeader, .myFooter, .contentDiv { color: blue; }```
      * This is the best of the two and you should get use to it as it will save you tons of lines of code and make your code way more legible.
      * Conversely, you may think it‚Äôs funny that they call the opposite of DRY -  WET programming, which they have given the following titles to:  "write everything twice", "we enjoy typing" or "waste everyone's time"
4. Box Model
  * In our first class, we touched on this a bit, but didn‚Äôt give it a formal title. 
  * Box layout means that all elements can be thought of as boxes. In our first assignment, we thought of all divs as content boxes that held other things in them (like russian nesting dolls)
  * However, each element has a box too
  * There are 4 main parts to the typical box model: (draw the following on the board or show picture from breathcode)
    * Content - this is what is inside the box
    * Padding - this is spacing between the border and content (inside box also)
    * Border - this is the edge of the box
    * Margin - this is spacing between the outside of the box and the next element over in any direction. (which could be the edge of the page, another div, a paragraph, or even an image. )
  * You can also have a background color or image, this will show in the content area of your box.
  * Additionally, you have properties that are important to your elements such as: width and height, display, position, etc.
    * Width and height - talk about the dimensions of the box
    * Display - talks about whether an element is visible or not, also refers to how it can be positioned in relation to other objects
      * Block - sits on it‚Äôs own line (takes up whole width)
      * Inline - can sit next to other elements (works like a span)
      * there are tons of others so you will have to read up to understand them all, but those are the two main ones
      
> üí° Recommend that students go over the CSS and HTML cheat sheets that we have available on the breathco.de platform under Assets. 


## Start next project `(2:30min)`

Start the project with the students, show them how to plan your by drowing the boxes first.

![HTML/CSS Strategy](https://github.com/breatheco-de/exercise-instagram-feed/blob/master/strategy.png?raw=true)
 
Explain that all projects will have to be delivered by next week using the breathecode platform.
 
Answer any questions.
 
At end of class, remind them to finish the the postcard with CSS and simple instagram.
 
Encourage them to use the Chat or to DM me on slack. Work on the Reading ahead of each class and do the Repl‚Äôits, THEY HELP!

days.label: Command Line
days.homework: At the end of the class, present the students with the GIT project & please ask each student to start coding its corresponding part of the website.
days.description: A text editor and the console, that's all you need to be a great coder. Time to master the second one.
days.instructions: Teach the command line to your students, use the CMD challenge to make it very fun! Start with a small explanation about the importance of the CMD and then explain each command after its respective challenge is completed.
days.teacher_instructions: Teach the command line to your students, use the CMD challenge to make it very fun! Start with a small explanation about the importance of the CMD and then explain each command after its respective challenge is completed.
days.extended_instructions:
Check if students were able to finish the previous projects, answer questions and encourage them to finish.
 
 ## `10 min` Small theory about the command line (do not explain the commands)

```md
‚ö† Ô∏èIMPORTANT:
Please don't explain every command, it is better if during the challenge the students find the commands in google or in the breathecode lesson.

Students can do searches like: "How to get into a computer directory", etc.
Force them to start searching in google!!
```

- Computers can be entirely managed without a windows interface, you can do everything from the command line.
- Make sure to make students understand how important the command line (developers use it every day all the time and it is impossible to avoid).
- Relative path vs absolute path.
- Explain that we are in Gitpod, which uses ubuntu and we have to familiarize we the ubuntu command line.
- Talk about the file hierarchy and how is represented in the command line, what the dot  .  and double dot  ..  represents. Draw on the board a file hierarchy and show if at the same time how the command line shows it (compare both).
- Explain the use of the autocomplete command: [using tab one time for autocomplete or two times to show options](https://www.howtogeek.com/195207/use-tab-completion-to-type-commands-faster-on-any-operating-system/).
- This is a [very good series of videos](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AO0jzD1hpXc&t=267s&index=8&list=PL8A83A276F0D85E70) explaining the command line that students can **watch later.**
- Share this [cheat sheet with the most used commands.](https://ucarecdn.com/61c6474b-5760-43db-9a2c-dfbea2ccdd76/Comandlinecheatsheet.pdf)

## `1:20 hr` Start The CMD Challenge

- Have students create a project in Gitpod
- Help them to clone the repo for the project (paste it in the slack channel so they can use the link)**
    1. git init
    2. git clone
- Run the react presentation

```md
üìù The command line will make students practice the most important commands, explain each command after the each challenge is completed, the student that successfully completed it can explain to other students.
```

## `1:30min` Take some time the class explaining git in a general way

Git will be the first applicacion we will be using inside the command line, students must read about it and wat videos about it.

### What is git?

Git is an online, central code storage that allows developers to manage a code base in teams.

Some of the things you can do with git include:

1. You can collaborate on projects easily
2. see a history of revisions
3. Roll back to previous versions if a revision fails (version control)
4. Resolve code conflicts so that 2 developers don‚Äôt overwrite each other‚Äôs code.

Git is a necessity to any developer working today as it‚Äôs resolved many of the issues of working on a team or keeping version history on a project.

## For Next Class

Next class we will review GIT in more detail. If you haven‚Äôt already, please read the lesson on GIT in the breatheco.de platform.**

lessons.title: How to use GIT: Version Control System

key-concepts: Do not explain Git with SSH credentials  in detail, students must use HTTP
It will be impossible to avoid using Github
days.teacher_instructions:
Start explaining Github as a social network, how it stores 90% of the world's codebase, how you can review all major coding projects, follow the most influential developers, and the role of open source.

Then explain GIT without being very technical, the "Github for poets" video does a great explanation, we will get more technical the next class that we will collaborate on building a landing page.
days.extended_instructions:
# Welcome to Github

**Welcome everyone, Check if they were able to finish all the lessons, exercises, and projects up till now.**

### Explaining Github

1. As we mentioned in previous classes, Github & Git have become a staple of every development workflow.

2. You will use this in EVERY development job you have from here forward.

3. Show the main profile screen and explain parts

    - Use [https://github.com/gaearon](https://github.com/gaearon) as example.
    - Explain about the github activity graph, how github tracks your entire activity and other developers and recruiters can see it


4. Explain how to create a repository

    - click repository tab > new repo button > fill out data

5. Show what a repository looks like

   - explain the contents of the repository and the importance of the Readme file in a project.
   - Show popular repositories like react, vue, flask, etc. Show them the README files.
   - show [the git collaboration readme](https://github.com/breatheco-de/exercise-collaborative-html-website) as an example 

## The role of open-source

- Explain about open source, how the most important projects in the coding world are open source like: Chrome, Windows, React, Pyhton, Flask, Django, etc.

- In the open source world anyone can pull request anything, there are maintainers that review and approve changes.
- 4Geeks Academy syllabus is open source and you can Pull Request (lessons and projects)


## `1 hr` Project: Fixing Misspells as the perfect Open Source Ice-Breaker

Show students how every lesson on breathecode has the github logo on the top, and you can contrute or fix any lesson by clicking on the github logo and then editing the lesson file on github.
    
Create repositories for all previous workspaces and upload all your code to their corresponding repo‚Äôs. Then submit the assignments on your student.breatheco.de  **(DUE MONDAY). Also, work on all repl‚Äôits and get caught up. Be ready for the next class which is on Wireframing and design process.**

## `1hr` The student External Profile

Encourage students to do their first pull request with the student external profile: [sep.4geeksacademy.co](https://sep.4geeksacademy.co)

days.label: Forms

lessons.title: Understanding HTML Input HTML Text Area and Forms...

days.description: Forms are responsible for user interactions, they are the first way the internet had to send request to the backend and saving on databases. It's time to learn the most basic way of interacting with backend applications.
days.teacher_instructions: Explain how HTML forms work, how to use the most important inputs, and prevent errors with things like "required" or being very specific with the input types.

days.label: Bootstrap
days.description: Then, Bootstrap came to profesionalize websites, removing 99% of the layout pain. Everything is a component from now own.
days.instructions: Explain bootstrap and how it solves 99% of the pain. Everything is a component from now own.
key-concepts: Workflow: Identify the components, Copy&Paste them and finally customize them
Helper/Utility Classes that come with bootstrap
days.teacher_instructions: Explain bootstrap and how it solves 99% of the pain. Everything is a component from now own.
days.extended_instructions:
Welcome everyone, see how the weekend went.
  * How many got to code Saturday at the downtown campus?
  * How many worked on the exercises?
  * Did everyone finish the 2 projects? (postcard and simple Instagram)

Today we are going to review Bootstrap which is going to completely simplify your life as a developer.
***(Total time: 20 min-25min)***

1. Bootstrap (open the breatheco.de lesson on Bootstrap - day 3)
  * So what is Bootstrap? We touched on this a bit last class, but Bootstrap is a framework that was developed to simplify front end design/development.
  * It has tons of components to simplify the process of styling your elements.
  * Each component is built around classes that they have constructed, which you will include in your html projects.
  * The biggest take away will be that with Bootstrap, you will have most of the baseline css work done for you and all that will be left is tweaking elements to your unique needs. This removes the heavy lifting in CSS.
    * Let‚Äôs take a look at their website really quick and see what I mean. (open the bootstrap website)
2. Components
  * Navbar
    * this is an example of a really useful component that will be in almost every project you create.
    * every site needs a navigation, and Navbar allows you to create either simple or complex navigation effortlessly.
  * Card
    * Ask students: If you think about your instagram project, What can you visualize having represented as a card?
      * Answer: Each of the picture/text combos are perfect representations of a card.
    * Cards are really easy ways to represent data in a nice visual format by combining a picture and text.
  * Modal
    * This element isn‚Äôt purely css. It will require Javascript to make it work.
    * Modals are kind of like pop-ups in that they overlay all elements on the page and display some data. They have many uses and can give a super polished look to a project when used correctly.
    * Let‚Äôs look at an example: https://getbootstrap.com/docs/4.0/components/modal/#live-demo
3. Here is your basic Workflow with Bootstrap Components:  (assuming you have your design already planned)
  * Identify the components you will need.
    * visit the site, search through components and find what you will need.
  * Copy & Paste the element into your code in the specific area it is needed
    * For example, if you have a Navbar, it will typically be the top of your page.
    * So within the body, but either in a section or div that you created to house your header is where you will paste the code.
  * and finally customize the component for your specific design
    * This is where the fun stuff comes in.
    * Bootstrap takes the guesswork out of the beginning and allows you to ‚Äúbootstrap‚Äù or spin up a project quickly.
    * However, once you have the project created, you need to customize each component using CSS to make it unique to your specific design.
      * Adjust colors
      * maybe decide between rounded or rectangle buttons
      * Possibly slight adjustments to form elements, etc.
    * This is where you will use all of the awesome CSS skills you have been practicing.
4. Helper/Utility Classes that come with bootstrap
  * So, in addition to the components, bootstrap also adds helper classes.
  * These are classes you can attach that do things such as control margin or padding, control borders, or even float elements.
  * For example, if you wanted no margin on the left of the element, you can add the class ```ml-0``` to the element and it will set the left margin to zero.
5. Now that you understand how these components and helper classes work and what they do for your projects, it‚Äôs time to review the most important part of what bootstrap does for you.
  * Layout using Grid system
    1. Explain 12 column layout and how it works
        * every line is a Row
        * this row holds columns
        * every Row on a page has 12 columns
        * each column has its own spacing between (gutters)
        * columns are equally measured in percentages so that they are responsive.
    2. When you build layouts, you specify how the columns will react at each screen size.
        * the sizes are determined by breakpoints which are defined in bootstrap (you can read these on the documentation)
        * the basic sizes are: col, col-xs, col-sm, col-md, col-lg, col-xl
        * To see these breakpoints and their corresponding sizes, check out the bootstrap layout documentation and scroll to the section on ‚Äúgrid‚Äù
6. One more thing I want to touch on is Fonts.
  * Bootstrap doesn‚Äôt set font size on HTML (which is the common practice for the documents base size)
  * It assumes a base font size of 16px (which is the browser standard) and specifies a starting value of 1rem on the body.
  * This allows all fonts to scale up relative to that size. It is recommended in responsive design to use rem units for fonts because the scale in respect to the base document font
  * You will want to familiarize yourself with measurement differences between EM, REM, and PX.
    * PX = pixel measure and is a standard measure used on base sizes (doesn‚Äôt not change with resize of browser; fixed size)
    * EM = is a measurement that is relevant to the parent (Ex. parent font = 20px, child font = 1.5em = 30px)
    * REM = is the same as EM, except it‚Äôs relative to the base document font (set on html in your css). As mentioned earlier, if you don‚Äôt override this, the base font is usually 16px.

Have class work on bootstrap instagram.

Answer any questions. Remind them this project is due by Friday.

days.label: Intro to JS
days.homework: Students need to finish the Excuse Generator, make the replits about javascript and the layout for the Random Card Generator
days.description: HTML & CSS are great, but the world needed interactive pages (not just beautiful text documents). Javascript comes to help us generate HTML & CSS based after the initial text document has already loaded and also re-write the website live based on the user activity.
days.instructions: Begin the class by having students push their changes to the repo, then view the project with the class. The excuse generator is a great way to explain how Javascript and HTML/CSS can play together. Do it with the students as you explain all the programing Key Concepts. Use the VanilaJS boilerplate, that way students will start getting used to it
days.teacher_instructions: Coding Practice Day: Students take turns on the screen, one at a time, one student share the screen and tries completing the exercise, and the others help, every student must go around at least two times. Stop the class and explain JS concepts when needed.
days.extended_instructions:
# Javascript Variables, DataTypes and Arrays

Start anwering any questions students may have.

## `20min` Javascript Intro:

**Warning**: Please do not explain the DOM or Events, also, don't explain loops or functions yet. Students will be overwhelmed.

### Why Javascript?

Static websites are just blog posts, but was about interactive applications like Instagram, Facebook, etc.?

Javascript lets us create dynamic HTML and CSS based on user or system interactions, for example:
- Adding an `li` to a `ul` when the user clicks on a button.
- Showing a banner or ad (publicity) based on the user IP address.
- Ask for information to a database.
- Write on a database using AJAX.
- etc.

Basically: Javascript its a programming language to generate HTML and CSS (text) based on events.

## The`<script>` tag:

All javascript must be done on a separate sheet (best practice).
You have to import to put that tag **right before the body closing tag**.
The code execution starts on the `window.onload = function(){}` like this:
```
//index.js

window.onload = function(){
    //your code here
}

//you can declar other functions here, but please don't write code outside functions
```

**Warning**: Carefull explaining the windown.onload, because today we are not suppose to overwhelme them with events and functions.

### Explain Variables:

Variables are javascript‚Äôs version of containers that hold some information.

An example of this is:

1. Let‚Äôs say we needed to store someone‚Äôs birthday for an age verification script
2. One of our variables might be: `var day = 29;`
3. There are three things going on here:
    - First, the computer interprets the letters VAR as the beginnig of a variable declaration.
    - After `VAR` it must always come the variable name: in our case is called `day`.
    - Secondly, we are storing a value of 29 in that variable.
    - Finally, notice the syntax. All javascript lines typically end with semicolon. There will be some cases where you don‚Äôt use semicolon and we will learn those later but for now, all lines are with semicolon.

3. Given that we defined the var above, `var day = 29;` if we want to display it for testing, we can show use the javascript console:
    - Explain how to open the google inspector console
    - So to display the variable, you would use: `console.log(day);`
    - will print on the console `29`

### Data Types

You can store 6 differnt types of values: Strings, Integers, Booleans, Arrays, Objects, Functions, Null and Undefined.

- Boolean - true/false
- String - always in quotes
- Number - any type of number -  integer numbers, negative numbers, decimal numbers, floats, etc.
- Undefined - nothing was set or specified for the variable. so the variable has no value
- Null - When a database or function returns nothing, it returns null
- Array - data sets [2,3,4,"cat",242,"d"]
- Object - You can explain objects like real life objects that are comprised by other datatypes, you can use the analogy with HTML Tags because the tags have properties taht describe them further. Objects behave the same way.

Note: Data Types on Breatheco.de: [http://content.breatheco.de/lesson/what-is-javascript-learn-to-code-in-javascript#data-types](http://content.breatheco.de/lesson/what-is-javascript-learn-to-code-in-javascript#data-types)

### String Contatenation

Suming two integers its not the same as suming two strings, as web developers we are going to be creating HTML using Javascript, we will contatenate like crazy!

### Arrays

Since we just learned what an array is, let‚Äôs look at some basic properties of an array:

1. value or item: The value stored on each position.
2. index or position: the position of the given value in the array `note: the first position starts at 0`
3. length - the total length of the array

Declaring an array [http://content.breatheco.de/lesson/what-is-an-array-define-array](http://content.breatheco.de/lesson/what-is-an-array-define-array#how-to-declare-an-array)

To initialize an array , you can use the following:
```js
let myArray = [];
```
This defines the array as an empty set so that you can add values later.

Note: Don‚Äôt use, use let or const.

You can also initialize an array with a value in it**
```js
let myArray = [1,2,3,4,5];
```
Displaying the value of an array using console, we can show it as `console.log(myArray[0]);`

Updating a specific position: `myArray[4]=3;`

Generating a random number using `Math.rand()`

## Javascript Exercises and Learnpack

Explain to the students how they learnpack exercises work:

There are 4 main exercises: Begin JS, Arrays, Functions, and Mastering Javascript, and they are supposed to be done in parallel because they share the same concepts E.g: You need to know about strings to know about functions because you probably will use a string within a function.

1. They can start any series of exercises by clicking on the gitpod button in GitHub (using the gitpod extensions)
2. Once the exercise engine is loaded and the exercises are running they can click "next" for each exercise.
3. If the engine is down the can type `learnpack start` to restart the engine.

They have to complete all exercises by the end of the Bootcamp and repeat some of them if possible, particularly the "arrays" exercises.

## Start Practicing

Open the begin js exercises and have the class take turns on the screen to complete each exercise during the class hours hours.

Note: You can stop the class anytime and explain a javascript concept if you see they need to re-enforce the concept.

days.label: Excuse Generator

project.title: Code an Excuse Generator in Javascript

assignments.title: Code an Excuse Generator in Javascript

days.description: The only way to master coding is thru practice, today we'll show you how practice must be done, and we hope you continue practicing on your own time.
days.teacher_instructions: Begin the class by having students push their changes to the repo, then view the project with the class. The excuse generator is a great way to explain how Javascript and HTML/CSS can play together. Do it with the students as you explain all the programing Key Concepts. Use the VanilaJS boilerplate, that way students will start getting used to it
days.extended_instructions:
## `20min` JS Review

- Start the class going over the same concepts of js again, make the class answer your questions about: 
- 1. What are variables?
- 2. What are data-types? 
- 3. What is the scope? 
- 4. What are functions?
- 5. What is the window.onload? Why do we use it?
- 6. What is a string and how to concatenate strings?
- 7. What is an HTML String? how can we generate HTML Strings as js devs.

## `2 hrs` First JS Project (Excuse Generator)

- Read the instructions with the students, and introduce the problem: How can we create a excuse? What are the pieces that we need to build?
- Students MUST discuss with each other how to approach the problem of creating an excuse, guide them.
- The project does not have to be fully finished at the end of the class, some students are slower than others, but at  least tgey should be half way and with a clear idea.
- To include the excuse into the document you can tell them tu use `document.querySelector('body').innerHTML = excuse;` but don't try to explain the DOM, that is for another class and they are already overwhelmed.

Explain to the students how they learnpack exercises work:

There are 4 main exercises: Begin JS, Arrays, Functions, and Mastering Javascript, and they are supposed to be done in parallel because they share the same concepts E.g: You need to know about strings to know about functions because you probably will use a string within a function.

1. They can start any series of exercises by clicking on the gitpod button in GitHub (using the gitpod extensions)
2. Once the exercise engine is loaded and the exercises are running they can click "next" for each exercise.
3. If the engine is down the can type `learnpack start` to restart the engine.

They have to complete all exercises by the end of the Bootcamp and repeat some of them if possible, particularly the "arrays" exercises.

## `30min` Continue Practicing and give homework

Open the function js exercises and have the class take turns on the screen to complete each exercise during the 3 hours.

Note: You can stop the class anytime and explain a javascript concept if you see they need to re-enforce the concept.

days.label: Arrays & Loops

lessons.title: It's Time To Learn What is an Array

replits.title: Learn Javascript Arrays and Loops Interactive

days.description: Primitive values like numbers and strings are the most basic way of storing information, but sometimes you want to store more than one value when they are related to each other, for example; A list of student names. For that we have Arrays. The first, most simple and most used data structure in Javascript.
days.teacher_instructions: Go over javascript quickly and all the concepts, focus particularly on arrays now. Explain the concept thoroughly and then allow students to complete the exercises by taking turns on sharing the screen.
days.extended_instructions:
# Looping and Arrays

Welcome class.

## `1 min` Remind students of the importance of finishing the JS exercises

Students should be focused on completing those exercises: Begin JS, Loops, Arrays, Functions, and optionally Mastering JS.
Remind students that reading will do no help, this phase is about practice, practice, and more practice.

## `15 min` Review last class and everything about javascript that we have seen

- We started generating HTML Strings for the first time, that is the developer's ultimate goal.
- Data Types, Variables, and Arrays.
- Algorithms run from top to bottom, line by line.
- You can skip lines with conditionals, repeat lines with loops, and reuse lines with functions.
- Arrays have items (or values) and index (or position), they start at 0. And you can get the length with `myArray.length`.
- Concatenate strings using + and the new amazing type of quotes '`' that is easier for creating big dynamic strings.

## `10 min` Talk about looping: with and without arrays (for vs foreach).

- The main objective for a loop is to repeat a bunch of lines of code from the opening curly brace to the closing curly brace.
- There are several ways of looping but we will focus mainly in the `for` loop for now.
- Here is a 12min video explaining [all the different ways of looping](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=U3ZlQSOcOI0).
- You can add elements to an array with `push`.

## `10 min` Talk more in detail about functions

- Functions are the last thing to learn about basic algorithms (encouragement).
- You create a function when you find yourself doing the same thing all over.
- Function's purpose is to receive an input and return an output.
- The function stops executing after returning.
- Functions SHOULD USE VARIABLES declared outside of them (best practice).
- Anonymus function vs normal function.
- In javascript, we will only use arrow functions (no the original type of function) because they are more similar to other programming languages functions.

## Start completing the Arrays Exercises with the students

One student at a time sharing the screen to complete the exercise, the teachers help students when they see them going in the wrong direction, its like Peer Programming but there are a lot of navigators and just one driver.

days.label: Unit Testing

lessons.title: How to create unit testing with JEST

project.title: Your first unit tests with Javascript's Jest Framework

assignments.title: Your first unit tests with Javascript's Jest Framework

days.description: Quality Assurance is one of the most valued skills in big tech major companies, today we are learning how you can write code that tests your previously written code in an automated way. Welcome to unit testing!
days.teacher_instructions: Explain how unit testing works with a very simple example (sum function) and then show the students how the exercises are auto-graded with unite tests, open one of the simplest JS exercises, and show how the tests work. Then start with today's project.
days.extended_instructions:
# Practice Day (replits and projects)

## `5 min` Take any questions about javascript

Remind everyone that the all the replits about Javascript are extremelly important, the only way to become better is practicing.

## `10 min` Last review about JS (really fast)

- Everything starts on the window.onload
- A non declared variable value is `undefined` (this will help them read the console errors)
- If you forget to return, the function will return `undefined` (this will help them read the console errors)
- Our main purpose for a front-end coder is to **generate dynamic HTML and CSS**, you will be using algorithms to do so (the need to understand that for better react.js learning curve)
- All ways of looping are important, including the `for` loop because its the only one with total freedom and we not only loop arrays, we also loop for other reasons.
- Map vs Foreach: In react we will map all the time because it creates a new array and that is really important.
- Functions goal is: Receive an input and return and output. The execution stops after returning.
- What is `myArray.find` and `myArray.filter`. In React we will use them all the time.

## `2 hours` Last Repl.it/Project Intensive before The DOM!!

‚ò¢ üò∞ ü§Ø Ô∏èStudents are overwhelmed!

This is the most delicate part of the course, there is a **lot of risk on students droping**. Please make sure all of them do lots of replits today.
Do not teach new concepts!

üí° Tell students that today the MUST ask questions after 5 min of being stuck, They cannot try on their own for 30 minutes before asking, not today.
They will have planty of challenges to keep learning on their own tomorrow.

## `45 min` before the class finished, do the student exernal profile with them:
    - Breafly explain open source and why its important, examples of great software build like that.
    - Explain that developers like to collaborate in open source and why its important for them.
    - Pull Request are the best mechanism for collaboration because you don't need permission to push.
    - Students are required to do a real collaboration to a real open source project by the end of the class to an open source project.
    - Talk about the importance of having green dots on your github activity graph.
    - Explain YML breafly.
    - Help them do they YML file and push a draft of their profile (don't worry about content, just structure).
    - Once they do their PR they can see their live profile because we are [automatically merging](https://mergify.io/) and deploying.
    - If the automatic merge does not occur, its probably because their YML has syntax problem, you can review the travis execution log on the pull request details.

Note: They students don't have to worry about the content, today its just about the YML and making it work and show up on the [student list](http://sep.4geeksacademy.co/students/).

5. After their `Student External Profile` is done, they may continue doing replits and finishing their previous projects.

days.label: Master JS
days.description: You have a lot of things to catch up on, finish and deliver. Make sure to review all of your assignments. Use your time wisely and ask for questions!...

days.label: The DOM
days.homework: Finish the Random Card and pending replits, start DOM & EVENTS replits
days.description: Ok but how do we use Javascript to build websites? You have to interact with the DOM whenever an event occurs
days.instructions: Do the Random Card but focusing a lot on the workflow (how to plan and begin coding), re-inforce the ONLOAD and PRE-LOAD main events and how to change CSS with JS, make students do the 'Map Of Events' to strategize, start using the breathecode-cli and vanilla-js
key-concepts: Always use Arrow Functions, never normal functions
Never use var, always let or const
Use querySelector() to select DOM Elements just like you do with CSS
Add/Remove CSS Classes to DOM elements
Please do not attempt to explain the Webpack Config.
days.teacher_instructions: Explain the DOM and start the exercises about the DOM with the entire class, have them present and discuss the exercises as a class.
days.extended_instructions:
# Day 10 -  The DOM

Before the class, teacher assistants can sti with students and responde any coding questions.

## `30 min` Introduction about the DOM

Now we are going to be using Javascript to create or change HTML code: The DOM.

- Once the browser receives the server response it starts building The DOM until `window.onload` gets triggered.
- The runtime is everything that happens after loading.
- The DOM is a LIVE hierarchy that represents the HTML document.
- The DOM its not the same as the source code, the source code will be the first version of the DOM ants its quickly overitten by the LIVE changes.
- Draw a DOM example on the whiteboard vs a its corresponding HTML code.
- Show on the browser the google inspector with the DOM opened (the elements tab).
- Show how it changes live based on the user/system activity clicks/mouseover/etc.
- The `querySelector` and `querySelectorAll` will be our main way to use The DOM, the other methods are deprecated: getElementById, byTagName, etc.
- Once you select DOM element and store it on a variable you can change any of its properties: Styles, Classes, Values, etc. ANY PROPERTY!
- Code on the google inspector console a small 2 line script showing a querySelector and changing a style:

```js  
const anyDOMElement = document.querySelector(‚Äò.anyClass‚Äô);
//changing a background
anyDOMElement.style.backgroundColor = ‚Äòblack‚Äô;
//adding a class
anyDOMElement.addClass('d-none');
anyDOMElement.removeClass('d-none');
// inner html
anyDOMElement.innerHTML = "html string that will be included inside the selector"
```

## `10 min` Reinforce what is webpack and npm

Just a brief reminder about bundling, `npm install`, `npm run build`, etc.

## `2:20min ` Start the DOM exercises

Each student rotates the screan, one at a time.

days.label: Random Card
days.description: Work on your current projects and exercises.
days.teacher_instructions: Do the Random Card but focusing a lot on the workflow (how to plan and begin coding), re-inforce the ONLOAD and PRE-LOAD main events and how to change CSS with JS, make students do the 'Map Of Events' to strategize, start using the breathecode-cli and vanilla-js
days.extended_instructions:
## `20 min` Reinforce what is webpack and the vanilla js boilerplate

1. Explain how to start using the boilerplate.
2. Show students that the README.md has everything they need to start coding.
3. Show how to see errors on the terminal.
4. Show how to see errors on the INSPECTOR.

## `20` Strategize the project!

React instructions carefully with students and plan a strategy!

- Start strategizing the HTML/CSS.
- After having one hard coded card and suite, how can you change it dynamically?: 
    - Approach A: Dynamically changing the card css classes. E.g: having a class `card` and 4 classes `diamons`, `club`, `spade` and `heart`.
    - Approach B: Using `domElement.styles.color = 'red';` instead of using classes.
- Use the whiteboard with the students.
- Every student must participate.

## `2:20` Code the project

Once the strategy is clear in written down, help students implement it.

## Ask students to finish replits about the DOM.

days.label: Cond. Profile
days.description: What we call "thinking" is basically the process of making decisions based on some information (variables) that we have available. You can replicate the same behavior in a computer by using conditionals and logical operations.
days.teacher_instructions: Ask students to gather and create a flow chart on the whiteboard with the decision process behind building the html for the profile card project. Finish conditional profile card and all previous exercises.

days.label: Intro to React

lessons.title: JavaScript Import and Export of Modules
Learn React Here : React Js Tutorial

days.description: But working with the DOM can get tricky and it's resource consuming, for that and many other reasons libraries like React.js got popular in the last couple of years. The let you create HTML and CSS using JS in a very intuitive way
days.teacher_instructions: Make students create their first react components and explain the use of JSX. Only talk about functional components, class components are deprecated and we will be using only hooks.
days.extended_instructions:
# Continue working on the Landing Page

## `5 min` Take any questions about javascript/react/bootstrap/html/css

Remind everyone that doing the replits about Javascript is extremelly important, the only way to become better is practicing, not reading or waching videos.

## `20 min` Review React.js again.

- React is about components (component names MUST be written in PascalCase)
- You build components by creating functions (the only function in the worls of JS that MUST start in capital letters)
- Functions must return HTML.
- Those functions can receive information in the form of Properties `<Tag property={value}>`
- Now its className intead of class.
- Everything starts on ReactDOM.render()
- JSX is great because you can mix HTML with JS using braces/curly brackets.

```
üî•  We are not using component classes

Class Componets are legacy, we recommend to ignore them as they will disappear in the next 1-2 years.
```

## `15min` Show the class again how to create a component

- Create a simple component like the bootstrap card or the bootrap modal.
- Make sure the component does not have a state, only props.
- Explain the props in detail.


‚ò¢ üò∞ ü§Ø Ô∏èStudents are overwhelmed ! Don't talk to much because they won't listen.

üí° Tell students that today its not the day to be brave and find your own solutions, today its about asking questions after 5 minutes.

No new conecpts today, just go over react again and focus in the process of creating components.

You can create a react component for each bootstrap component.

Explain the difference between Functional components and or class components and the render function. Landing page project should be a code along at start, then groups at end.

Create a Component like a Class
Create a Component like a Function

## Continue working on the Landing Page

## `5 min` Take any questions about javascript/react/bootstrap/html/css

Remind everyone that doing the replits about Javascript is extremelly important, the only way to become better is practicing, not reading or waching videos.

## `20 min` Review React.js again.

- React is about components (component names MUST be written in PascalCase)
- You build components by creating functions (the only function in the worls of JS that MUST start in capital letters)
- Functions must return HTML.
- Those functions can receive information in the form of Properties `<Tag property={value}>`
- Now its className intead of class.
- Everything starts on ReactDOM.render()
- JSX is great because you can mix HTML with JS using braces/curly brackets.

```
üî•  We are not using component classes

Class Componets are legacy, we recommend to ignore them as they will disappear in the next 1-2 years.
```

## `15min` Show the class again how to create a component

- Create a simple component like the bootstrap card or the bootrap modal.
- Make sure the component does not have a state, only props.
- Explain the props in detail.


‚ò¢ üò∞ ü§Ø Ô∏èStudents are overwhelmed ! Don't talk to much because they won't listen.

days.label: The State
days.description: So far you know that React components have properties (props), but there is one more important concept in react components: The State.
days.teacher_instructions: Do not explain react components with classes, it's still being used in the industry but less every day. Let's focus on mastering the useState function.

days.extended_instructions:
# Creating Components with States

## `10 min` Take any questions publicly

Remind everyone that doing the exercises about Javascript is extremely important, the only way to become better is practicing, not reading or watching videos.

## `10 min` Review React.js (yes, again)

- React is about components (component names MUST be named in `PascalCase` notation)
- You build components by creating functions (the only function in the worls of JS that MUST start in capital letters)
- Functions must return HTML.
- Those functions can receive information in the form of Properties `<Tag property={value}>`
- Now its className intead of class.
- Everything starts on ReactDOM.render()
- JSX is great because you can mix HTML with JS using braces/curly brackets.

## `20min` Go over the component `useState` hook again

- Properties are defined **ouside** of the component.
- The State is defined **inside** of the component.
- The state is needed when information inside the component will **change over time**.
- You can have as many states as you want.
- Talk about controlled inputs with an example.


## `2:25 min` Start the todolist with the students

Any other project the student may have until this day (like the Traffic Light) is supposed to be done on their own time.

- You can help them a lot on this exercise, but always do it on the whiteboard.
- Help them do the strategy first and later help them complete the exercise.
- This exercise is challenging for the majority of the students, but you will be able to manage if you continue helping them individually.

days.label: React Router

lessons.title: Global state with the Context API

project.title: Create a Todolist with Context.API and Flux

days.homework: Sit with every project team and discuss how to split the code into Views and React.Components, students must finish the home layout by next class

assignments.title: Create a Todolist with Context.API and Flux

days.description: But some react components will never be re-used, they behave more like page or layout. We will call those components: 'Views'... React will help us connect them together to create our main website navegation
days.instructions: React Router + React: How to create components that behave like Views (layouts) and match them with URL Routers.

Debugging code with the Chrome Source Tab
days.teacher_instructions: This project is all about URLs and Routing. Each student must build two views/pages. List of
days.extended_instructions:
# Advanced React Boilerplate 

## `5min` Questions about Context and React Router

If someone asks about redux tell them we focus on Flux instead of Redux because its a lot easier to setup and its also widely used on the market.
Redux is a simplification of Redux, students will no have problems setting it up in the future but we are interested in learning the process behind.

## `10min` Review the React and Context API

- React is about components (component names MUST be written in caps)
- You build components by creating functions or classes (both MUST start in capital letters)
- Review how to create a class vs functional component
- The component objective is to create HTML.
- You can pass props to compoentns `<Tag property={value}>`
- You can persist those variables to the DOM using `this.setState`
- API Calls (fetch) should be done on `componentDidMount`
- Review how to code a fetch
- The Context API is about: View, Actions, Store (MVC)
    - The view renders and triggers actions
    - Actions setStore
    - store is just a store, you have to model your data and initialized it
    - fetch call must be done on component did mount.

## `45 min` Live Coding

-Show students the way you would do this project. Take all the questions and make questions as well if they don't take the initiative.

## `2:00min` Continue working on the Starwars Blog

How to display "loading" before data arrives
How to use POSTMAN (set environment variables and use collections)
JSON is a Javascript object but as a TEXT
What is serialization and how to do it
Why use several request types: GET, POST, PUT, DELETE

lessons.title: Mastering Databases: What is SQL Database

Do not explain composer that much (do the analogy with NPM) and do not explain WP-CLI to much either, start using it and students will learn by doing

Then, start using the WordPress boilerplate to create your first Custom Post Types for each table and create the properties using Advanced Custom Fields.
days.extended_instructions:
# Data Modeling whith UML

## `5 min` Take 5 minutes to explain the difference beween data-structures and data-models

You can think about data-structures like he RAM Memory repersentation of data-models, for example:

- Data structures are stuff like: Arrays, Queues (FIFO, FILO), Classes, etc.
- Data models are ways of structuring the database.

The data-structure of your Reac.tjs projects will: The Store (RAM Memory).
But the data-model is only represented on the backend database.

## `20 min` Today it is about: Data Modeling

[This video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UI6lqHOVHic&list=PLUoebdZqEHTxNC7hWPPwLsBmWI0KEhZOd) shows how to create a UML diagram, make students watch the video.
Explain the basics of UML with a simple Car dealer example: Vehicle, Client, Purchase.

- What are the possible data-types in a car dealer? Number, Boolean, String, etc.
- What properties can a Vehicle, Client or Purchase have?
- What are tthe relationships between the models (one-to-one, one-to-many, many-to-many)?
    - How many Vehicles a Client can have?
    - How many y Purchases a Client can do?
    - How many Vehicles can a Purchase contain?

## `2:30` Data-Modeling project

Work on today's project.

days.label: Authentication
days.homework: Students must work on the project
days.instructions: Work with students on the project
days.teacher_instructions: Work with students on the project
